19231 - Jordan- 
Two years ago you wrote a BBA asking if I was single,
I thought it was my friend‚Äôs joke but still said yes and ready to mingle. 
Our first date at blue state made my heart tingle
And my eyes twinkle.

At home my family asked what‚Äôs up with all that giggles, 
You see, 12 hours of time difference did not make our feelings dwindle.
You learned my language and we are now kinda trilingual.

Now you like to read your kindle,
With me on your side and our cats in the middle. 

Oh life is simple, 
And your little surprises add all the sprinkles. 

It‚Äôs Valentine‚Äôs Day again and this time I‚Äôve turned the table:
Me writing you a BBA while you are eating a bagel.

18588 - CS19 Shriram appreciation

Shriram, you are absolutely god-tier. Thank you for making our intro CS class at Brown an enjoyable and overall encouraging experience. You are such a wholesome human being and a great lecturer, but more than that, we really appreciate you as a mentor. From the beginning of placement, you tried to make us more independent and aware of the fact that we now have our own responsibilities and must be cognizant of our actions, both as students and as future contributors to society. Now, at the tail end of the class, we are walking away with more than an understanding of how to program; we understand why the skills we picked up matter, and more importantly, how to ethically be using those skills in the context of today‚Äôs world. We are absolutely floored with the amount of effort you put into transitioning this course into an online format, being super open to feedback, and still covering a wide breadth of topics. If we were given the opportunity, nearly all of us would take 19 again in a heartbeat; your enthusiasm is that infectious. Now for some easter eggs: 

Do you know how to write in Pitman shorthand? 

What‚Äôs the difference between (-: and <-; ? Are there any other emojis that you save for 173? Why are they ‚Äúbackwards?‚Äù

Humor: students 37 and 52 not caught, overall strong joke suite; high-check
Smilies: mystifying, ominous, yet inviting; solid <-;
Ability to make me desire spending 4 hours catching a single chaff: check+
How much you will be missed: fun how-much-missed() -> Number: 1 + how-much-missed() end

Needless to say, many of us are sad that this class is ending, but glad that we have all the memories and funny Campuswire posts to take with us. Thank you SO much. 

Sincerely, 
CS19 students :)

18550 - I spent a good part of my early teenage years dreaming of idealistic love that would sweep me off my feet, the passionate, breathless, overwhelming kind. Then I had my heart broken, many times, and I began to think that the only kind of love worth anything, would be the one that would come along when I was older- the boring, sustainable kind, the kind you find when you‚Äôre thirty and looking to settle down. 
You trudged in, slow and steady, breaking down walls, fighting all my attempts to push you away. I was terrified at how easy it was, terrified that this wasn‚Äôt the passion I secretly craved, terrified that I would find the sustainable ten years earlier than I planned. But you walked in through the door, grabbed me in your arms, and took my breath away. Like you have every day ever since. With you I find sustainability in passion, contentment in monotony, and a completeness I never imagined was possible at this very confused stage of my 21 year old life. 
I don‚Äôt know what will happen to us and where life will take us. I know that if I could choose my life right now, I would pick growing old by your side in a heartbeat over every crowning academic and professional glory I could choose to have. But, that‚Äôs irrelevant. Regardless of the future, I am so supremely grateful to you for showing me how happiness should feel, how being valued, and respected, and loved can go hand in hand with passion, (how sometimes that can mean binge watching New Girl instead of having sex) and how taking that leap of faith for love is always worth it. If not for now, if not for this, for what now and this will mean for the future. 
Word of advice from a reasonably well-experienced senior: Take the leap, kids. It works out sometimes, and when it doesn‚Äôt, it takes you closer to a time it will work out.

18095 - to everyone else who's looking to the future and seeing no hope: 

i love you. i'm sorry the people who came before us have broken their promise of a future that will get better. i know it's hard. i love you. i know we're all doing our best. i know that most of us will leave Brown knowing that things have to change, and that even if the change looks huge and insurmountable, there will be enough of us to chip away at it however we can. 

and even if we can't destroy it all, we will leave less behind for the people -- or perhaps, whatever life is born from our ruins -- to clean up, to suffer with. if nothing else, we can leave behind an earth that's trying to heal. if nothing else, we can be people who are trying to heal. 

i love you. i know you're doing your best. i'm sorry. i love you. i love you. i love you.

16762 - You better read this because this is the most honest I‚Äôll ever be able to be with you, and there‚Äôs a reason I chose today of all days to do this. And you‚Äôre probably laughing that I‚Äôm writing this here of all places. 
Used to love you and used to think you understand me, but now when you do things without realising or even thinking about how they make me feel I realise how wrong I was all along. I understand why you do what you do, and I‚Äôm never going to ask you to change anything for me because that‚Äôs not my place anymore. But this makes it so hard for me to move past what happened and see you the way I used to. I still love you though, although not in the same way as before. It‚Äôs the kind of way where hearing about you doing something good or getting something you wanted makes me feel warm and glow up for you inside. The kind of way in which if you‚Äôre doing something that might get you hurt I‚Äôll worry about you. But I won‚Äôt ever tell you that, because I‚Äôm scared of trusting you with anything I feel. I want you to be happy in every possible way, even about the thing that sometimes makes me sting with bitterness. I want to trust you again and see your face and hear your voice and watch your name light up my screen and not feel my heart sink and my body tense up because I‚Äôm suddenly (even if momentarily) reminded of how it felt to sit numbly as you chose to not choose me a little more everyday, and blamed myself for it. 
But I care about you, and think about you, and often when something exciting happens whether it‚Äôs a new person I‚Äôm flirting with or a new thing my dog does or a fight I have with my family you‚Äôre the first person I want to talk to. But I can‚Äôt, because it hurts, and I would rather love you from afar than hate you all the time. 
If you‚Äôre wondering what this is about or if it‚Äôs about you, this probably doesn‚Äôt concern you.

16059 - I am sitting by myself alone contemplating about the joy that was stripped from my life after the lockdown. I remember the days when I would walk by blueno and laugh at how ugly it is. I remember the times I would stop on the main green between classes and entertain my eyes with its beauty. I remember times I see a beloved one passing by and talk with them for 20 minutes and show up late for my class. I remember the happiness and livelihood in my heart when I am being called across thayer. I remember the excitement when everyone is talking about that fish dish at the ratty or the special new dessert. I remember the long lines for the omlette and how I would rather stay hungry than to wait. I remember Gail's warm smile when she swipes my card. I remember the nice kids at Brown who will help you without knowing who you are. I remember my stressful times and all the people who helped me. I remember the empathy my professors showed towards me. I remember the basement of the sci li and I wish to forget that. I remember the sunlab and how it stings. I remember the chem labs and how useless they are. I remember I hated that life. I remember it was boring. I remember I was miserable. I wish I remembered to pause and appreciate its beauty. I wish to remember the nice things in my life. I wish I continue to remember my gratitude to these days. I wish to remember to live the beauty in my everyday. I wish to get back to that life.

15403 - You're still in Providence, or so I believe anyway. I am also in Providence still, but you know that already. (After all, where else would I be?)

We were close. But we haven't talked at all this spring semester. That's because you've made it abundantly clear, since the winter break, that you don't want to talk to me.

I still don't know what happened.

It's ok. You've hurt me before. I reacted badly and hurt you even more. We made up for a semester, and now you're hurting me again. But that's ok.

There is so much I want to tell you, but I won't.

After the summer, I'll (hopefully) be gone from Providence. For good. In all likelihood we'll never cross paths ever again.

Strangely, I'm happy for you. You implicitly told me to f off. That's the first time I see you stand up for yourself. Although, I wish you had the strength to tell me explicitly, and tell me why.

You won't have to, of course. Because I won't reach out again.

Goodbye.

Yours lovingly,

15112 - SENIOR SCRAMBLE ROUND 3 - ""UNDERGRAD OMELETTE""

Hi everyone, due to the possibility that Brown students might be going home at some point later in the semester, the senior scramble team has decided to hold an additional round of senior scramble! If classes are cancelled, this will be our final round of senior scramble. If they are not cancelled, then we'll still have the additional round right before senior week.

There is one TWIST with this round: we've gotten countless requests to have a round of senior scramble that allows seniors to match with students who are not seniors, and other requests for underclassmen to be included in the pool for the matching process. Thus, we've decided to call Round 3 of Senior Scramble the ""Undergrad Omelette"", where all undergrad students can participate.

Rules:
- All undergrad Brown students can participate, and can put down the name of a Brown student in any class year
- Up to 5 names can be submitted by Saturday, March 14 at 11:59pm
- Matches will be privately emailed to both parties on Sunday, March 15
- A match DOES NOT imply any degree of sexual consent. Be respectful of your matches and seek consent just as you would in any other relationship.
- Any questions should be emailed to brownscramble2020@gmail.com

Fill out the form at https://tinyurl.com/brownscramble2020-3

Ready, set, scramble!

14837 - - the space in between -
There's so much that I cannot say
So much that I cannot bring myself to put into words
To put into air
To put into the world
When after they have been set free then they cannot be caught back and hidden away again
Before they cross the space in between us.
But if I could
Set down lyrics to these thoughts and snippets
I would write the colors of your summer dresses
Sing the arc of your lashes and the waves of your hair
Somehow describe all that you mean to me.
But my words aren't enough.
I can't capture the echoes of your voice in my heart long after it's faded from my ears
Or the way I remember any of the other moments
That likely never meant so much to you.
Still
If I were to make an attempt,
Put words on paper and try to sift my fears and doubts from the space in between
I think that all that would remain is
I love you.

To Mariya Gedrich

14350 - It's time for SENIOR SCRAMBLE ROUND 2!!

Is there someone in the Class of 2020 who you've had crush on for a while, but haven't had the guts to ask out? Maybe someone from your freshman year unit or an FYS way back when? Or maybe someone you've just met recently and you've been seeing around the GCB? Well, now's your chance! Get ready for Round 2 of Brown Senior Scramble for the Class of 2020!!!! Just in time for Valentine's Day!

Our team is currently planning on holding one more round of senior scramble after this one, right before senior week.

It goes like this: you submit up to five names to our form. If someone who you listed also submits your name when they fill out our form, it's a match!!

Rules:
- Only members of the Class of 2020 or Class of 2020.5 can participate
- Up to 5 names can be submitted by Thursday, February 13 at 11:59pm
- Matches will be privately emailed to both parties on Friday, February 14
- A match DOES NOT imply any degree of sexual consent. Be respectful of your matches and seek consent just as you would in any other relationship.
- Any questions should be emailed to brownscramble2020@gmail.com

Fill out the form at https://tinyurl.com/brownscramble2020-2

Make sure to like our page at https://www.facebook.com/brownscramble2020/ for all the latest info.

The turnaround is quick, and the more people that fill out the form, the more likely people are to get matched!

Ready, set, scramble!!

14234 - I admire people who are happy inside as they look outside. Everyday I put on a facade of emotions in front of my friends/those I care about when almost every night I come back home and feel a gaping hole inside me that I try to anxiously but fail miserably to fill -- it's been food these days that I chew and spit out or swallow and throw up multiple times throughout the day. I want to be fixed. I can't find the source. Nothing happened. Or Brown happened. My entire life happened? I've been hating every moment since moving to the states as a child. Brown happened because I can't make myself trust or like a single "friend" I made here, though I pretend my best to make them feel they're my favorite people ever. I feel vulnerable here, like a chick on the ground after falling from its nest that can be crushed under an unknowing heel at any moment. I don't know how people survive in this environment. I've been away from family enough to get used to home not being home, but the more the years that accumulate in me without home I feel myself breaking. Maybe I just want the attention, just for one person to notice I'm not the bubbly, hyper, happy-go-lucky girl I portray everyday. I don't want to die. I just want this kind of life to end. And a life without Brown is a broken pause button, no better than death. I say I wanna be fixed but do I There are no wants inmy life. There are only needs. I need to be fixed but I don't know how to want that for myself. I don't know how to want the best for myself rather than need it.

13967 - To all you who are reading and waiting for your name to one day appear in a post, who are shrinking more and more as you scroll through pages and pages of shoutouts, never one with your name attached‚ÄîI feel with you.

Please know that many someones have felt admiration for you‚Äîfor your spirit, your enthusiasm when you get into the topic you love, that brilliant observation you made, for the way that you look, flush-faced and breathless as you walk into a room on a windswept day, for that feature of yours that you've always felt self conscious about, but to them, is perfectly charming. Also know that so often, these thoughts go unspoken, silenced by fear of embarrassment, fear of causing discomfort, by the moment passing, by the fact that we've all trained ourselves to let these admirations pass by. Know that just because the appreciation people feel for you is silent, does not mean that it is nonexistent.

For all you who are reading, I challenge you: let's be each other's admirers. Embrace the pleasant discomfort. Don't let all the random, mundane appreciations you feel slip away unvoiced, but share one here and there. Let's normalize a culture where showing appreciation and admiration doesn't have to be confined to an anonymous page or limited to occasions of remarkable achievement or generosity, but can be shared day-to-day, face-to-face, accompanied by a perhaps unfamiliar, but no less warm smile.

12301 - It's been a long, hard four years at Brown.

Is there someone in the Class of 2020 who you've had crush on for a while, but haven't had the guts to ask out? Maybe someone from your freshman year unit or an FYS way back when? Or maybe someone you've just met recently and you've been seeing around the GCB? Well, now's your chance! Get ready for Round 1 of Brown Senior Scramble for the Class of 2020!!!! Just in time for *spooky season*.

Our team is currently planning on holding 3 more rounds throughout the school year: one towards the end of this semester, one around Valentine's Day, and one right before senior week.

It goes like this: you submit up to five names to our form. If someone who you listed also submits your name when they fill out our form, it's a match!!

Rules:
- Only members of the Class of 2020 or Class of 2020.5 can participate
- Up to 5 names can be submitted by Wednesday, October 30 at 11:59pm
- Matches will be privately emailed to both parties on Thursday, October 31
- A match DOES NOT imply any degree of sexual consent. Be respectful of your matches and seek consent just as you would in any other relationship.

Fill out the form at https://tinyurl.com/brownscramble2020-1

The turnaround is quick for this one, and the more people that fill out the form, the more likely people are to get matched!

Be sure to like our official Facebook page at https://facebook.com/brownscramble2020/ to get the most up-to-date information.

Ready, set, scramble!!

10605 - Hey everyone,

There was a policy change announced in Today@Brown last night about sophomores being required to stay on meal plan.

We think that its grossly unfair to not let us have the choice or even the option to apply to be allowed off meal plan and we plan on voicing our concerns to the Office of the Dean of the College via an open letter of concern and a list of names in support. 

If anyone else is upset with the new policy and would like a change, please add your name to the google sheets and take a look at the google docs! We welcome any new ideas or changes!

We admire our right to not being broke and have food at the same time.

Here's a Google docs with the letter of concern: 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/164HcqD-Y_DEvMUeELJgnBN-P_8QP3EsKGZxq3tPKbMA/edit?usp=sharing

And here's a spreadsheet for names in support:

10418 - When I wake up, it is not the list of the things to do today that I want to see.
When I wake up, it is the sudden message from my old friend back home that I want to see.

When I go to classes and lunch, it is not the small talk that I need to do with my friends that I want to do.
When I go to classes and lunch, it is sharing of laughter and funny stories that I want to have with my friends.

When I finish my classes, it is not the pressure to study and keep up with the good grades by the society and people that I should care.
When I finish my classes, it is a walk that I go on and the music I listen to at the park alone that I should care.

When I eat dinner, it is not the complaints of how much work we have that I want to have.
When I eat dinner, it is the catch up and how our life are going that I want to have. and maybe a little bit of complaints.

When at night, it is not the loneliness that I always want.
When at night, it is often somebody whom I can talk about everything including my shit, and my past. Both good ones and bad ones alike.

Everyday, I want somebody I can hug, and somebody I can cry on shoulder as hard as I actually want to.

9579 - SUPPORT CAMP RYSE (Refugee Youth Solidarity through Education)! 

Camp RYSE, formerly known as BRYTE Summer Camp, is a five-week academic enrichment program for refugee youth in Providence (K-12). Our mission is to foster community, confidence, and joy among refugee youth through creative, inquiry-based learning and leadership development. Our community is built on asset-based, joyful learning; community participation and family engagement; youth leadership; and a deep commitment to creating a space for students can celebrate their identities and build friendships across common experiences of migration, resettlement, and adjustment to a new environment. 

This summer, Camp RYSE is looking to continue supporting and enrolling over 100 refugee Providence youth, while hosting our program in an accessible and air-conditioned space and expanding compensated leadership opportunities for our youth. We fundraise 100% of our budget, and would very much appreciate support (through advertising, donations, etc.) in order for Camp RYSE to be safe and successful for campers.

This community is built on doing what we can, when we can. We are forever grateful for the many ways each of you contribute. You can click here to share or donate -- you can also click here to view information about our ongoing snack drive. Thank you so much for your support.
-CAMP RYSE family

https://fundly.com/camp-ryse?fbclid=IwAR3IYFTmfUcjPxUc6PzVfWKw1BdPSnjfX_f5096bwSiFIg4e_-TEP71E_Ns
